attributes.title: Decomposing the focus effect: Evidence from eye movements

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value:
Decomposing the focus effect: Evidence from eye movements

Morwenna Hoeks, Maziar Toosarvandani & Amanda Rysling

other.value:
To make sure that the items in all experimental conditions of Experiment 1 and 2 will be equally acceptable, all materials will be normed using naturalness judgments. In this norming study, participants will be asked to judge on a 4-point Likert scale to what extent they find the target question/answer pairs form a natural discourse. The question/answer pairs will only be used as material in the eye tracking study in case the norming study shows that there is no significant difference in the naturalness ratings between our conditions. In the case that we do observe a trend for a difference between conditions that doesn’t reach significance, we may add this to the models used to analyze our eye-tracking data. The items of Experiment 2 will be combined with the items of Experiment 1, by treating the presence of the particle in Experiment 2 as an extra within-items factor.

The norming study also aims to establish whether the target is considered a natural alternative expression to the alternative mentioned the preceding question (in ALT conditions) and vice versa. This will be done by testing both the intended question/answer pair, as well as the question/answer pair in which the position of the target and the alternative are switched. That is, in the norming study both the question/answer pair in (7) and (8) will be tested. If both are judged equally well, we take this to suggest that both ice cream and chocolate cake are plausible alternatives to each other in the given context.

    (7) 	Q: ...did Sarah want chocolate cake for dessert?	
	        A:  I think Sarah said she wanted ice cream for dessert, but I'm not sure. 

   (8) 	Q: ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert?	
                A:  I think Sarah said she wanted chocolate cake for dessert, but I'm not sure. 

We will test both these versions of our items as a between-subjects manipulation: one group of participants (n=48) will be presented with the set of items that will be used in our eye-tracking study (i.e. items like (7)), while a second group of participants (n=48) will be presented with the version of all the items that have the target and the contextual alternatives switched, as in (8).

sample.value: Each experiment will have 4 conditions with 48 items in total using a latin square design. This gives us 12 observations per condition per participant. In total, we will be testing 96 participants, thus yielding a total of 1152 observations per condition per experiment.

analyses.value:
Data of interest on the target word and the next (spillover) region included the duration of the first fixation, the gaze duration (the sum of fixations on the word before leaving it for the first time), the go-past time (the sum of all fixations from first fixating the word until leaving it to the right, including regressive re-reading), the total time, and the proportion of regressions out of the region. 

To assess the effects of focus, newness and the presence of alternatives on fixation durations, linear mixed effects models will be fit to the raw reading time data, using the lme4 package (Bates & Sarkar, 2007) for mixed effects models in R, an open source envi- ronment for statistical computing (R Development Core Team, 2007). The fixed effects of interest in the first experiment will be the two-level factors focus and newness. The fixed effects of interest in the first experiment will be the two-level factors alternatives and newness. Random slopes and intercepts for both items and participants will be included, except when the resulting models do not converge. In general, differences will be considered significant with t-values greater than 2. 

Bates, D. M., & Sarkar, D. (2007). lme4: Linear mixed effects models using S4 classes, R package Version 0.998875-6. Madison, WI.

R Development Core Team (2007). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. Vienna: R Foundation for Statistical Computing.

outliers.value: All trials where a subject blinks near the initial fixations on the critical word or produced a long (>100 ms) saccade near the critical region will be removed from the analysis.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable will be reading times on the critical word and surrounding regions. That is, analyses are only planned thus far for reading times on the target sentence. Examples of target sentences in Experiment 1 and 2 are given in (3) and (4) respectively, in which “|” indicates the boundary of a region. 

(3) |reg1 I think Sarah said she wanted |reg2 ice cream |reg3 for dessert, |reg4 but I'm not sure.

(4) |reg1 I think Sarah said she wanted |reg2 only |reg3 ice cream |reg4 for dessert,|reg5 but I'm not sure.

The critical region will contain only the critical word. In Experiment 1 and 2, this will be region 2 and 3 respectively, i.e. the word ice cream in the example sentences (3) and (4) above. The critical region in both experiments may be extended three characters to the left to account for parafoveal preview effects. 

Because of the exploratory nature of the study, we analyze the post-critical region (region 3 in Exp1 and region 4 in Exp2) both as one word and as multiple words. In the example sentences in (3) and (4) this means we analyze for as a separate region as well as for dessert as a region. In Experiment 2, the particle will be analyzed as a separate region of interest (region 2).

Reading times will be measured by first-pass RTs, gaze durations  (the sum of fixations on the word before leaving it for the first time), go-past RTs (the sum of all fixations from first fixating the word until leaving it to the right, including regressive re-reading), total RTs, probability of regressions out of the region and skipping rates.

conditions.value:
Each experiment will have 4 conditions, using a within-subjects and within items 2x2 design. In Experiment 1, the factors we manipulate are newness (with levels NEW and GIVEN), and focus (with levels NARROW FOCUSED and BROAD FOCUSED). In Experiment 1, we manipulate these factors using question/answer pairs. More concretely, the form of the preceding question will determine whether the target word inside the target sentence will be discourse new or given (in the sense of Schwarzschild, 1999), by either mentioning the target word in the question or not. Orthogonally to this manipulation of newness, the preceding question will determine whether the target word receives narrow focus or broad focus. The target sentence itself, will be exactly the same in all four conditions. An example of one experimental stimulus in all four conditions is given in (5) below.

(5) Sarah is a very picky eater, but I forget…
a. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert, or chocolate cake?    NF, G
b. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert? 					BF, G
c. ...did Sarah want chocolate cake for dessert?				NF, N	
d. ...what did Sarah say?							                BF, N
e. Target: I think Sarah said she wanted ice cream for dessert, but I'm not sure. 

In Experiment 2 the relevant factors will be newness (NEW vs GIVEN) and the overt presence of alternatives in the preceding context. (ALTERNATIVES vs. NO ALTERNATIVES). Material for the second experiment will be very similar to that of the first, except for the fact that the target sentence in Experiment 2 will contain the particle only in the position directly preceding the target word, as shown in (6). 

(6) Sarah is a very picky eater, but I forget…
a. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert, or chocolate cake? 	ALT, G
b. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert? 					NOALT, G
c. ...did Sarah want chocolate cake for dessert?				ALT, N	
d. ...what did Sarah say?							                NOALT, N
e. Target: I think Sarah said she wanted only ice cream for dessert, but I'm not sure. 

The particle will ensure the target will be narrow focused in all conditions of the second experiment. The crucial manipulations by the preceding question will therefore not be that of broad versus narrow focused, but the factors manipulated here will be that of newness (new vs. given) and that of the presence of explicitly previously mentioned alternatives (roughly,  alternative expressions that could replace the expression in focus; see Rooth, 1992). The newness manipulation will be the same as in Experiment 1. The manipulation of alternatives will work as follows: in the ALT conditions, an alternative to the target ice cream will be mentioned in the preceding question. In the example item in (6), this is chocolate cake. 

Rooth, M. (1992). A theory of focus interpretation. Natural language semantics, 1(1), 75-116.

Schwarzschild, R. (1999). GIVENness, AvoidF and other constraints on the placement of accent. Natural language semantics, 7(2), 141-177.

hypothesis.value:
In the two proposed experiments, four questions are being asked. Since the two experiments are explorative in nature, we do not have clear hypotheses about the answers to these questions, but we can say something about how potential outcomes relate to the different possible answers to these questions. 

The first experiment addresses the following two questions:
1. How does linguistic focus as manipulated by discourse context affect eye movements in reading?
2. How does newness of an expression modulate eye movements in reading of that expression?

In both experiments, we will use an eye-tracking-while-reading paradigm, in which we measure reading times on a target sentence that is preceded by a question. We thus use question/answer pairs, in which our experimental manipulations will always be an effect of differences in the preceding question.

In Experiment 1, we manipulate the form of the preceding questions using a 2x2 design, but the target sentence will have the same form in every condition. More concretely, the form of the preceding question will determine whether the target word inside the target sentence will be discourse new or given (in the sense of Schwarzschild, 1999), by either mentioning the target word in the question or not. Orthogonally to this manipulation of newness, the preceding question will determine whether the target word receives narrow focus or broad focus. An example of one experimental stimulus in all four conditions is given in (1) below.

(1) Sarah is a very picky eater, but I forget…
a. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert, or chocolate cake? 	NF, G
b. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert? 					BF, G
c. ...did Sarah want chocolate cake for dessert?				NF, N	
d. ...what did Sarah say?							                BF, N
e. Target: I think Sarah said she wanted ice cream for dessert, but I'm not sure. 

As potential outcomes, we may find main effects of focus and/or newness, as well as interaction effects between the two. If we find increased reading times on the target word (or subsequent region) when the target is focused, we can conclude that linguistic focus slows down reading. If we find increased reading times when the target is new, we can conclude that newness slows down reading. It is possible that we find a main effect of focus in the absence of a main effect of newness, and vice versa. It is also possible that we find a significant interaction between newness and focus such that reading times on the target are longer when the target is both new and focused. 

The second experiment builds on the first, and addresses the following question:
3. How does explicitly mentioning focus alternatives in the preceding context of a focused expression modulate eye movements in reading of that expression?

Material for the second experiment will be very similar to that of the first, except for the fact that the target sentence in Experiment 2 will contain the particle only in the position directly preceding the target word, as shown in (2). 

 (2) Sarah is a very picky eater, but I forget…
a. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert, or chocolate cake? 	ALT, G
b. ...did Sarah want ice cream for dessert? 					NOALT, G
c. ...did Sarah want chocolate cake for dessert?				ALT, N	
d. ...what did Sarah say?							               NOALT, N
e. Target: I think Sarah said she wanted only ice cream for dessert, but I'm not sure. 

The particle will ensure the target will be narrow focused in all conditions of the second experiment. The crucial manipulations by the preceding question will therefore not be that of broad versus narrow focused, but the factors manipulated here will be that of newness (new vs. given) and that of the presence of explicitly previously mentioned alternatives (roughly,  alternative expressions that could replace the expression in focus; see Rooth, 1992). The newness manipulation will be the same as in Experiment 1. The manipulation of alternatives will work as follows: in the ALT conditions, an alternative to the target ice cream will be mentioned in the preceding question. In the example item, this is chocolate cake. 

Depending on the results of the first experiment, we may or may not expect a main effect of newness in the second experiment as well.  

As for the effect of alternatives, we may expect that explicitly mentioning alternatives in the preceding context facilitates processing of the focused expression in the target sentence. That is, since the interpretation of expressions like only involves exhaustification over a set of alternatives, we might expect that encountering such an expression triggers a search for the set of relevant alternatives. If this process of exhaustification indeed has any psycholinguistic relevance, it may be facilitated if the context already explicitly provides such alternatives. As a potential main effect, we might therefore expect increased reading times on the target in the NOALT conditions (i.e. in case no alternatives to that expression are mentioned in context). In addition, we might also expect an interaction between the presence of alternatives and newness, such that the NOALT, N condition yield longer reading times than any of the other conditions. 


Finally, a comparison between the first and the second experiment could then answer the fourth question:
4. How does the presence or absence of focus particles affect eye movements in reading of focused expressions associated with those particles? 

Since the only difference between materials of the first and second experiment is that of the presence of a focus particle, we can directly compare the NF conditions in the first experiment to the ALT conditions in the second experiment. 




Rooth, M. (1992). A theory of focus interpretation. Natural language semantics, 1(1), 75-116.

Schwarzschild, R. (1999). GIVENness, AvoidF and other constraints on the placement of accent. Natural language semantics, 7(2), 141-177.

q1.value: Does emotional awareness obey Weber's law?

q3.value: Though there is evidence to support an analogy between emotions and perceptual decisions, this analogy has never been extended to Weber's law. Weber's law has been seen to apply to many domains in sensation and perception. In this study, we would like to answer the question: does emotional awareness behaves like most other sensations, and obey Weber's law?

q4.value: In this work, we rely on the analogy between emotions and perceptual decisions, so we hypothesize that emotional awareness behaves like conscious (“perceptual”) sensation and obeys Weber's Law.  An alternative hypothesis is that emotion resembles “action” related perception, and as such does not obey Weber’s Law.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In this study we will run three experiments, which consist of three different tasks. 

The first task is the ellipse's task. In this task, subjects will be exposed to different sized ellipse's, and their task will be to determine whether the ellipse presented to them at each step is "thinner" or "fatter", compared to a perfect circle. In the ellipse's task, a fixation point will appear first for 500 milliseconds. After that, the ellipse to which the subject will respond will appear. This ellipse will be presented until the response. After responding to the image, a blank screen will appear for 500 milliseconds.

The second task is the emotional task. In this task, subjects will be exposed to emotional stimuli with established norms (NAPS, Marchewka, urawski, Jednoróg, &Grabowska, 2014). For every emotional stimulus, the subjects will need to determine whether this emotional picture is making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. Before the presentation of an emotional stimulus, a frame (used as fixation points) whose size is lightly larger than the photo will appear for 500 milliseconds. The emotional picture will then be presented inside the frame until the response. After responding to the image, a blank screen will appear for 500 milliseconds.

The third task is the gambling task. In this task, subjects will make a choice between 2 keys, and will then win or lose up to three NIS. For every winning or losing amount, the subjects will have to answer one of two questions: (1) whether the gamble outcomes is making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. (2) whether the gamble outcomes are small or big. Each gambling trial will start with a frame painted in green or red that will appear for 500 milliseconds. Each frame will be followed by a number (winning or losing amount) that will appear at the center of the screen. Whether the number is pointing at a win or a loss, will be determined by the color of the frame (green= gain, red= loss). The amount will be presented until response, which will be followed by a blank screen for 500 milliseconds.

Experiment 1 will consist of the ellipse's task only. This experiment is a within subject's design, with two factors: ellipse's height (3 levels), and width (3 levels).

Experiment 2 will consist of the ellipse and the emotional task with trials of the two tasks interleaved. Participants will be told that we are studying the influence of emotion on their circle perception; that we manipulate their emotion using pictures; and that we need to know how they personally feel in response to that picture. This experiment is a within subject's design, with four factors: ellipse's height (3 levels) and width (3 levels), emotion eliciting photos intensity (6 levels), and valence (2 levels). The NAPS pictures were selected according to their valence scores, so that six groups were created. For the first group the valence values will be around the value 2, for the second group the valence values will be around the value 3, and so on. The group of neutral stimuli (valence around 5) will not be used in the present study.

Experiment 3 will consist of all the three tasks: ellipses, emotional, and monetary gain/ loss. This experiment is a between subject's design, with six factors: group (2 levels), the deviation of the stimulus from the standard: ellipse's height (3 levels) and width (3 levels), emotion eliciting photos intensity (6 levels), valence (2 levels) and monetary gains/ losses (6 levels, winning/losing 1,2, or 3 NIS). 
In Experiment 2 and 3, each emotional trial or monetary gains/ loss trial will be followed by an ellipse trial.

In Experiment 3, subjects will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. Subjects assigned to the Group 1 will perform two separate sections. In one of those sections, subjects will perform the experiment as described for Experiment 2. In another section, subjects will perform the gambling task (see shortly). In the second group of Experiment 3, subjects will perform the gambling task, with the ellipses task, without the emotional stimuli task. This group will be asked about the size of the gamble outcomes, while Group 1 will be asked about the pleasantness of the gamble outcomes.

The purpose of having two different groups in Experiment 3 is to show that when subjects are asked to indicate whether a gambling step is pleasant or unpleasant, they do not treat this question in the same manner as they would treat a gain/ loss size question.

To summarize, in the first experiment subjects will perform only the ellipse task. In the second experiment subjects will perform both the ellipse task and the emotional task, with trials of these two tasks interleaved. In the third experiment, subjects will be divided into two groups: Group 1 will perform the ellipses task, the emotional task, and the gambling task. In the gambling task this group will be asked about the pleasantness of the gamble outcomes. Group 2 will perform the gambling task only, and will be asked about the size of the gambling losing or winning amount. This condition is required in order to provide evidence that pleasantness judgements do not simply reflect expected pleasantness that is based on the size of the monetary win/loss. Evidence for that will be different processing characteristics (As assessed with the LBA parameters) for the 2 tasks (see Givon et al., 2019). 

All key manipulations will be counterbalanced across subjects. All three experiments will begin with detailed instructions. In addition, the experimenter will provide a verbal explanation to ensure that the instructions are clear. 

In every experiment, there will be a practice block. During practice, the experimenter will be present in the room to make sure that the subject got the instructions right. After the practice block another four steps will be completed, and then the experiment will stop, given the subjects another chance to ask for further instructions.
 
Also, at the end of every experiment, the experimenter will ask the subject three questions: 
1. Please state in your words: what was your task in the experiment?
2. What strategy did you use in order to succeed in this task?
3. In your opinion, what was the goal of this experiment?

In case that the first experiment will not produce the expected results (the SV parameter from the LBA model will not increase with ellipse height and width), we will try another version of the experiment, this time instead of presenting the ellipse until the response is given, the circle will disappear after 200 milliseconds. The rationale is that responding to a present stimulus might invoke the action system which is known not to behave according to Weber’s Law, whereas responding to a remembered stimulus activates the perception system, which behaves according to Weber’s Law (Ganel et al. 2008). If the new version will not produce the expected results as well, we will have to consider additional alternatives before running the second and third experiment.

In case that the second experiment will not produce the expected results, then Experiment 3 will not be required anymore. There is also a possibility that because of a time limitation, Experiment 3 will not be implemented.

After running the first experiment, there is the possibility that we will change some aspects of the study design of Study 2 and 3. If changes will be needed, we will update those changes in an additional registration.

The second group will complete the ellipses and monetary gains/ losses manipulations only. In contrast to the first group, the second group will be asked about the size of the gain/ loss (is this bet result is big or small?) instead of whether the outcome of the bet feels (un)pleasant.

Participants will be recruited through online experiment system of Ben- Gurion University. Participant must have intact / corrected vision. In addition, in two of the three experiments, participants will be invited to participate based on their pre-screening depression score that needs to be in the lower two- thirds (given the highly aversive nature of some stimuli, and as justifiably dictated by our Ethics committee). If participants meet this requirement, they will receive an invitation to fill a further depression questionnaire. Only participants who will be within the normal range in the full depression questionnaire outcomes, will receive a link to sign up to the experiment. Subjects whose depression scores are in the clinical range will 1. Be compensated for their participation; 2. will be given an explanation regarding the meaning of this score; and 3. Will be offered to meet with a clinical psychologist for further explanation regarding possible directions to take.

Participants will be ungraduated students of ben- Gurion University, who will be paid (~35 NIS per hour), or that will receive course credit for their participation. In addition, in one of the experiments there will be a possibility to win money in a gamble. The subjects will get 20 NIS at the beginning of the experiment. In every trial of this experiment, subjects will be able to win or lose up to 5 NIS. At the end of the experiment, five of the gain trials and five of the loss trials will be selected at random and will be added\ subtract from their beginning amount (20 NIS). Of course, the subject will never lose more than their beginning amount. In other words, they will earn at least the 35 NIS per hour.

If, in the future, we will find a proper power analysis method, we may increase (but not decrease) the sample size in accordance.

question.value:
First, we manipulate the width and height of ellipses. The starting point for the manipulation was a perfect circle, with a diameter of 300 pixels. When we manipulate the ellipses height, the width remains constant at 300, and vice versa for width. There are three ellipses that are wider than the perfect circle, and three that are higher than it. 

In order to determine the ellipse height and width, we will conduct a small-scale pilot experiment (N=4) that contains multiple ellipses of varying widths or heights. The purpose of this pilot is to select total of six ellipses (three wider and three higher ellipses compare to a perfect circle), so that each ellipse will produce similar accuracy rate to the accuracy rate obtained for different valence levels of the emotional stimulus. We will use data that were previously gathered in our lab in order to calculate the accuracy rate for different levels of the emotional stimulus valence. We chose this stimulus selection method since too high or too low accuracy can create model estimation problems that we would like to avoid. Another reason to use this method is that the perceptual stimulus can serve as a closer benchmark to the emotional stimulus.

Second, we manipulate the emotional intensity of pictures. We will use emotion eliciting photos that have established norms. Each photo had been chosen based on its valence, intensity and category (animals, faces, etc.), So that every category will have a satisfactory representation in the study, that every value of intensity will have a satisfactory representation, and that each valence will have a satisfactory representation as well.

Last, we manipulate monetary gains/ losses, by using gamble trials. In every gamble trial the participant can win up to three NIS, or to loss up to three NIS.

In the ellipse's manipulation, participants will indicate (by a key press) if the ellipse they are seeing is "thinner" or "fatter" (higher or wider, respectively), compared to a perfect circle. 

In the emotional awareness manipulation, we will ask participants if the picture they are seeing is making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. 
In the gamble task, we will ask participants if the gambles results are making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. Also (in a separate experiment), we will ask participants if the gambles results are small or large. 

In every manipulation we will record RT and response choice for each answer.
We will use an evidence accumulation model, the liner ballistic accumulation model (LBA) with a focus on DR (drift-rate) and the across-trial SD of drift-rate (SV).

In this study we will use the method of fitting a hierarchical Bayesian evidence-accumulation model. This hierarchical method estimates parameters for each individual separately, but constrain these estimations with the population distribution (see Lin & Strickland, in press, Appendix, for details).

The evidence-accumulation model that we will use is the liner ballistic accumulation model (LBA). In its more standard applications, this model contains of five parameters: drift rate (v), the drift rate standard deviation (SV), non-decision time, starting point (SP) and response threshold (b) (St0- the range of non-decision time, is usually fixed at zero, since adding it to the model substantially increases fitting time, and since usually there is no substantial question that relates to it).

In this study we will use a method of model comparison to test some of our hypothesis. The fundamental idea in this method is to fit several different LBA models, and to decide which model fits the data best. To do so, we will create the null model (M1) with all its parameters set to be equal across different levels of the dependent variable in question. Then, we will create five more models (M2-M6), which in every one of those models a different parameter will set as a function of the dependent variable. The null model will serve as a comparison model to the other models. 

Because hierarchical modeling is a time-consuming process, we will use hierarchical modeling only for our main hypotheses. In addition, in order to interpret the data obtained from the hierarchical analysis, the Gelman-Robin index for each individual and for all subjects together must be less than 1.1. If we won't meet this requirement, or if the hypotheses under examination is not a main hypothesis, we will use simpler methods for estimating the model parameters. The simpler method treats the data as if they came from "one big subject".  This approach is based on maximum likelihood estimation, and issues BIC values for comparative model fit assessment. This method will conduct using 'rtdis' or 'glba' R packages.  Any model that will have a significant smaller DIC or BIC then M1, will account as a model that fit the data the best. This method will be used by us in the analyses of few of our hypothesis.

To test our hypothesis that emotional awareness obeys Weber's law, we first need to show that the LBA model is suitable to find evidence to Weber’s law even for physical stimuli. We thus intend to show that the LBA model can detect Weber's law for the perception of ellipses height and width. We term the related hypothesis “tool-validity hypothesis” (TVH) to mark the fact that it is not a core hypothesis. To do so, we will use the model comparison method, and fit several different LBA models to ellipses height and width responses. Model 1 (TVH-M1) is the null model with all its parameters set to be equal across different levels of the ellipses height and width. In Model 2 (TVH-M2), DR is a function of actual height and width. In model 3 (TVH-M3), SV will set as a function of the ellipse's height and width. We expect that in TVH-M7, SV will increase linearly with stimulus intensity, while DR will increase as the ellipse's height and width will move farther away from a perfect circle. If TVH-M7 is shown to be superior over TVH-M2 and TVH-M3, this will support our prediction. In every one of the four remaining models (TVH-M4- TVH-M6), a different parameter (SP, non-decision, b) will set as a function of the different levels of the ellipse's height and width. We will choose the best model to fit the data, based on the DIC or BIC differences between the models (significantly smallest DIC/BIC).  

In a case that less than 75% of the subjects will fit more to one model compared to the other model (can be deduced by the DIC differences for each subject in both models), we will perform another analysis. For this analysis we will randomly split the data into two separate data sets, so that each subject's trials will be equally distributed between the two sets of data. We than re-run the model with both new data sets, and examined whether the percentage of subjects to fit one model compared to the other model remain almost the same. If the percentage will remain quite like the percentages of the first analysis, we can conclude that the differences between both models are not coincidental. 
If our hypothesis is not supported by the data, we have two options: First, the LBA model is not suitable to express Weber's law. The second option is that something in the experimental procedure went wrong, then we can fix it and try again. Importantly, until (or whether) the tool-validity hypothesis is supported is a pre-requisite for testing the core hypothesis which is described next. 

In order to test our core hypothesis (that emotional awareness obey Weber's law), we will compare between several alternative models which are strictly analogous to the models we have described above, except for being applied to (un) pleasantness reports. 

The ellipses task is used for two purposes: (1) to create a validated reference-point to the emotional and gamble tasks. (2) To function as a disguise (subjects will be led to believe that we are examining whether emotional stimulation/ gamble outcomes affect perception of circles area). In order to create a validated reference-point, we will use the method of model comparison as described above, and apply it on the difference between tasks (ellipses, emotional, monetary gains/ losses). We expect to find that the model that will show to be superior over the other models, is the model that allows the SP parameter to vary between tasks. This hypothesis is in accordance with previous work conducted in our lab (Givon et al., 2019). 

As mentioned above, Experiment 3 contains of two groups. We will use the method of model comparison and apply it on the difference between these two groups (Both groups differ in the gambling task, so that one group is asked about the pleasantness of the gambling results while the other group is asked about the size of the gambling results). We do not know which model will show to be superior over the other models, but we only need to show any difference between the two tasks. But, because this is an exploratory analysis, we will use a more stringent criterion to that comparison (BF greater than 10 will considered as significant, twice our original criterion (BF greater than 5)).

We would also like to check for selective influence as means to validate the model and to replicate prior similar validation by Givon et al. (2019). To do so, we will once again use the method of model comparison, and compare between different levels of some of the depended variables (ellipses height and width, intensity, valance, gamble outcomes). We believe that the model that will have the smallest BIC for each of those variables, will be the model that allows the DR and the SV parameters to vary between different levels of the depended variables. If this prediction will be supported, this will serve as evidence for selective influence. As sanity check, we would also aspect to receive higher drift-rate for negative feeling, then for positive felling (as was found in previous work conducted in our lab).

In the third experiment, we will use gamble trials in order to put the emotional stimuli trials on a ratio scale. This will be done by comparing the DR parameter between gambles and emotional stimuli. For example, let us assume that on average, emotional stimulus whose norm is 6, have DR= 0.6. let's also assume that on average, for a gamble trial in which the participant has won two NIS, its drift rate is also around 0.6. in this case we will say that the pleasantness associated with seeing an emotional stimulus whose norm is 6, is equal to that associated with winning 2 NIS, and since NIS is on a ratio scale, we will be able to anchor DR (and SV) which are also on a ratio scale to another ratio scale. We will repeat the same procedure on all the (grouped by normative rating) emotional stimuli. Note that we are assessing the validity of Weber’s Law on two levels. One level is ordinal: whether SV increases with stimuli intensity. The other level is a ratio-scale level, that requires validation of the ratio-scale properties of DR and its relationship to the NIS scale.

In addition to examining our central hypothesis, we sought to decide on further debate from within the realm of emotion. There are two approaches for measuring affect rating. The first is the bipolar framework which employs a single bipolar scale ranging from positive to negative, and an additional arousal scale ranging from low to high. The second approach is the bivariate framework which employs that positivity and negativity are two different dimensions, and that arousal is not a dimension (that arousal is dependent on the negative and positive dimensions). 

In order to help decide between these hypotheses, we will use the polarity correspondence principle. This principle argues that when a stimulus and a response alternative correspond, the response selection will be faster than when they do not, and this will be primarily driven by the drift-rate (DR).  Another important term is Markedness. According to the Markedness theory, a term is unmarked when it is the dominant part within a dimension. A marked term is the less dominant part in that dimension. Markedness and polarity together can help decide between the bi-polar and unipolar approaches to valence.  

We specifically hypothesize (under the unipolar hypothesis) that DR will be higher for both positive and negative (unmarked, under the unipolar approach) when the response is made with the right hand (unmarked) compared to a left-hand response (marked). However, if the bipolar approach is correct, then the expectation is for faster responses when pleasant-unpleasant are mapped to right-left. In order to verify our hypothesis, we will compare RT between two groups of subjects (one group responds "pleasant" with their right hand, while the other group responds "pleasant" with their left hand). If we will find support for our hypothesis, we will also use the method of model comparison the check our hypothesis at the level of the DR.

We note that there is also the possibility that the response code from the ellipses\ gambling task will affect the responses and will thus make it difficult to test our hypothesis in the present design. Another interference can happen due to the classifying of the stimulus as pleasant or unpleasant (that one word is the negation of the other), or because subjects will never classify the stimulus as neutral. In those cases, we will consider conducting another experiment containing the emotional task only, with a different classifying task.

q20.value: If the estimated parameters will be reasonable (i.e. non-decision time will be greater than 0, and more reasonably greater than .15, and between .5 to 1), no transformation will be needed. If not, then a transformation might be needed. If we use a transformation, this transformation will conduct in order to control individual differences in minimal RT and RT variance (see Pereg & Meiran, 2019, Appendix, for details). This between-subject normalization procedure will only be applied in case that we do not use the hierarchical modeling.

q21.value:
We intend to employ hierarchical Bayesian estimation (as instantiated in the ‘ggdmc’ R-package). This estimation method yields DIC estimated per subject. Thus, for each subject, we will determine which model fits the data the best (lowest DIC). We will use Bayesian Binomial test to compare subjects DIC score that obtained from different models, in order to show that one model in superior to the other not just by chance. 

For the simpler methods for estimating the model parameters, we will use Bayes Factor (BF) to determine which of the models fit the data the best. In order to calculate BF, we will use this function BF = e0.5*ΔBIC.  We will treat the results as significant when BF will be greater than 5.

First, we will exclude emotional stimuli whose responses do not fit their original norms. For example, if an emotional picture item that has a score 5 (neutral score) in the norms, but in this experiment most subjects have rated this picture as negative, then this item will be excluded. In addition, for every stimulus that according to the norms is on one side of the scale (negative or positive), we need that at least 60% of the subjects will classify it as such. For example, if a specific stimulus norm is negative, then at least 60% of the subject's will still have to classify it as negative in order for that stimulus to remain in the analysis. 

Second, we will exclude subjects for whom a technical or equipment failure resulted in loss of more than 50% of their data (we do not anticipate any such subjects). We will also exclude subjects who seem not to understand the instruction (as identified by the questions at the end of the experiment, or as seen while the experimenter is present in the experiment room during the training block.  This decision will be taken before peeking at the RT-accuracy results of that subject). We will also exclude subjects whose accuracy rates are 2.5 SD less than the mean accuracy of the entire sample. 

Third, we will exclude trials with RT greater than 7 sec, or shorter than 200 milliseconds. Following, we will exclude trials with RT greater than 3.5 SD above mean RT (as determined per condition within subject).

q25.value:
We have collected data from a single experiment. In this experiment we manipulate circle sizes, and asked participants if the circle they are seeing is smaller or larger compared to a standard (fixed) circle. The circle to which the subjects respond was displayed in a randomly chosen position on the screen (screen center or 150 pixels above/ below the screen center). We found that when the circle did not appear in the center of the screen, there was no evidence for Weber law, but evidence for Weber law did appeared when the circle was displayed in the center of the screen. 

Subjects reported great difficulty in estimating the size of the circle when it did not appear at the center of the screen.  We hypothesize that the position manipulation made the experimental results indecisive. It is possible that the fixation point (which appeared in the center of the screen regardless of the stimulus location) confused the subjects and made it difficult to estimate the size of the circles. However, it is important to note that the data from the circles experiment is still under statistical analysis, and therefore should be treated with limited guarantee.

More information about the circles experiment can be found at the former pre- registration. link: https://osf.io/gzd9j.

registration_responses.q1: Does emotional awareness obey Weber's law?
registration_responses.q3: Though there is evidence to support an analogy between emotions and perceptual decisions, this analogy has never been extended to Weber's law. Weber's law has been seen to apply to many domains in sensation and perception. In this study, we would like to answer the question: does emotional awareness behaves like most other sensations, and obey Weber's law?
registration_responses.q4: In this work, we rely on the analogy between emotions and perceptual decisions, so we hypothesize that emotional awareness behaves like conscious (“perceptual”) sensation and obeys Weber's Law.  An alternative hypothesis is that emotion resembles “action” related perception, and as such does not obey Weber’s Law.

registration_responses.q8.question:
In this study we will run three experiments, which consist of three different tasks. 

The first task is the ellipse's task. In this task, subjects will be exposed to different sized ellipse's, and their task will be to determine whether the ellipse presented to them at each step is "thinner" or "fatter", compared to a perfect circle. In the ellipse's task, a fixation point will appear first for 500 milliseconds. After that, the ellipse to which the subject will respond will appear. This ellipse will be presented until the response. After responding to the image, a blank screen will appear for 500 milliseconds.

The second task is the emotional task. In this task, subjects will be exposed to emotional stimuli with established norms (NAPS, Marchewka, urawski, Jednoróg, &Grabowska, 2014). For every emotional stimulus, the subjects will need to determine whether this emotional picture is making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. Before the presentation of an emotional stimulus, a frame (used as fixation points) whose size is lightly larger than the photo will appear for 500 milliseconds. The emotional picture will then be presented inside the frame until the response. After responding to the image, a blank screen will appear for 500 milliseconds.

The third task is the gambling task. In this task, subjects will make a choice between 2 keys, and will then win or lose up to three NIS. For every winning or losing amount, the subjects will have to answer one of two questions: (1) whether the gamble outcomes is making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. (2) whether the gamble outcomes are small or big. Each gambling trial will start with a frame painted in green or red that will appear for 500 milliseconds. Each frame will be followed by a number (winning or losing amount) that will appear at the center of the screen. Whether the number is pointing at a win or a loss, will be determined by the color of the frame (green= gain, red= loss). The amount will be presented until response, which will be followed by a blank screen for 500 milliseconds.

Experiment 1 will consist of the ellipse's task only. This experiment is a within subject's design, with two factors: ellipse's height (3 levels), and width (3 levels).

Experiment 2 will consist of the ellipse and the emotional task with trials of the two tasks interleaved. Participants will be told that we are studying the influence of emotion on their circle perception; that we manipulate their emotion using pictures; and that we need to know how they personally feel in response to that picture. This experiment is a within subject's design, with four factors: ellipse's height (3 levels) and width (3 levels), emotion eliciting photos intensity (6 levels), and valence (2 levels). The NAPS pictures were selected according to their valence scores, so that six groups were created. For the first group the valence values will be around the value 2, for the second group the valence values will be around the value 3, and so on. The group of neutral stimuli (valence around 5) will not be used in the present study.

Experiment 3 will consist of all the three tasks: ellipses, emotional, and monetary gain/ loss. This experiment is a between subject's design, with six factors: group (2 levels), the deviation of the stimulus from the standard: ellipse's height (3 levels) and width (3 levels), emotion eliciting photos intensity (6 levels), valence (2 levels) and monetary gains/ losses (6 levels, winning/losing 1,2, or 3 NIS). 
In Experiment 2 and 3, each emotional trial or monetary gains/ loss trial will be followed by an ellipse trial.

In Experiment 3, subjects will be randomly assigned to one of two groups. Subjects assigned to the Group 1 will perform two separate sections. In one of those sections, subjects will perform the experiment as described for Experiment 2. In another section, subjects will perform the gambling task (see shortly). In the second group of Experiment 3, subjects will perform the gambling task, with the ellipses task, without the emotional stimuli task. This group will be asked about the size of the gamble outcomes, while Group 1 will be asked about the pleasantness of the gamble outcomes.

The purpose of having two different groups in Experiment 3 is to show that when subjects are asked to indicate whether a gambling step is pleasant or unpleasant, they do not treat this question in the same manner as they would treat a gain/ loss size question.

To summarize, in the first experiment subjects will perform only the ellipse task. In the second experiment subjects will perform both the ellipse task and the emotional task, with trials of these two tasks interleaved. In the third experiment, subjects will be divided into two groups: Group 1 will perform the ellipses task, the emotional task, and the gambling task. In the gambling task this group will be asked about the pleasantness of the gamble outcomes. Group 2 will perform the gambling task only, and will be asked about the size of the gambling losing or winning amount. This condition is required in order to provide evidence that pleasantness judgements do not simply reflect expected pleasantness that is based on the size of the monetary win/loss. Evidence for that will be different processing characteristics (As assessed with the LBA parameters) for the 2 tasks (see Givon et al., 2019). 

All key manipulations will be counterbalanced across subjects. All three experiments will begin with detailed instructions. In addition, the experimenter will provide a verbal explanation to ensure that the instructions are clear. 

In every experiment, there will be a practice block. During practice, the experimenter will be present in the room to make sure that the subject got the instructions right. After the practice block another four steps will be completed, and then the experiment will stop, given the subjects another chance to ask for further instructions.
 
Also, at the end of every experiment, the experimenter will ask the subject three questions: 
1. Please state in your words: what was your task in the experiment?
2. What strategy did you use in order to succeed in this task?
3. In your opinion, what was the goal of this experiment?

In case that the first experiment will not produce the expected results (the SV parameter from the LBA model will not increase with ellipse height and width), we will try another version of the experiment, this time instead of presenting the ellipse until the response is given, the circle will disappear after 200 milliseconds. The rationale is that responding to a present stimulus might invoke the action system which is known not to behave according to Weber’s Law, whereas responding to a remembered stimulus activates the perception system, which behaves according to Weber’s Law (Ganel et al. 2008). If the new version will not produce the expected results as well, we will have to consider additional alternatives before running the second and third experiment.

In case that the second experiment will not produce the expected results, then Experiment 3 will not be required anymore. There is also a possibility that because of a time limitation, Experiment 3 will not be implemented.

After running the first experiment, there is the possibility that we will change some aspects of the study design of Study 2 and 3. If changes will be needed, we will update those changes in an additional registration.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited through online experiment system of Ben- Gurion University. Participant must have intact / corrected vision. In addition, in two of the three experiments, participants will be invited to participate based on their pre-screening depression score that needs to be in the lower two- thirds (given the highly aversive nature of some stimuli, and as justifiably dictated by our Ethics committee). If participants meet this requirement, they will receive an invitation to fill a further depression questionnaire. Only participants who will be within the normal range in the full depression questionnaire outcomes, will receive a link to sign up to the experiment. Subjects whose depression scores are in the clinical range will 1. Be compensated for their participation; 2. will be given an explanation regarding the meaning of this score; and 3. Will be offered to meet with a clinical psychologist for further explanation regarding possible directions to take.

Participants will be ungraduated students of ben- Gurion University, who will be paid (~35 NIS per hour), or that will receive course credit for their participation. In addition, in one of the experiments there will be a possibility to win money in a gamble. The subjects will get 20 NIS at the beginning of the experiment. In every trial of this experiment, subjects will be able to win or lose up to 5 NIS. At the end of the experiment, five of the gain trials and five of the loss trials will be selected at random and will be added\ subtract from their beginning amount (20 NIS). Of course, the subject will never lose more than their beginning amount. In other words, they will earn at least the 35 NIS per hour.
registration_responses.q16.question:
First, we manipulate the width and height of ellipses. The starting point for the manipulation was a perfect circle, with a diameter of 300 pixels. When we manipulate the ellipses height, the width remains constant at 300, and vice versa for width. There are three ellipses that are wider than the perfect circle, and three that are higher than it. 

In order to determine the ellipse height and width, we will conduct a small-scale pilot experiment (N=4) that contains multiple ellipses of varying widths or heights. The purpose of this pilot is to select total of six ellipses (three wider and three higher ellipses compare to a perfect circle), so that each ellipse will produce similar accuracy rate to the accuracy rate obtained for different valence levels of the emotional stimulus. We will use data that were previously gathered in our lab in order to calculate the accuracy rate for different levels of the emotional stimulus valence. We chose this stimulus selection method since too high or too low accuracy can create model estimation problems that we would like to avoid. Another reason to use this method is that the perceptual stimulus can serve as a closer benchmark to the emotional stimulus.

Second, we manipulate the emotional intensity of pictures. We will use emotion eliciting photos that have established norms. Each photo had been chosen based on its valence, intensity and category (animals, faces, etc.), So that every category will have a satisfactory representation in the study, that every value of intensity will have a satisfactory representation, and that each valence will have a satisfactory representation as well.

Last, we manipulate monetary gains/ losses, by using gamble trials. In every gamble trial the participant can win up to three NIS, or to loss up to three NIS.
registration_responses.q17.question:
In the ellipse's manipulation, participants will indicate (by a key press) if the ellipse they are seeing is "thinner" or "fatter" (higher or wider, respectively), compared to a perfect circle. 

In the emotional awareness manipulation, we will ask participants if the picture they are seeing is making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. 
In the gamble task, we will ask participants if the gambles results are making them feel pleasant or unpleasant. Also (in a separate experiment), we will ask participants if the gambles results are small or large. 

In every manipulation we will record RT and response choice for each answer.
registration_responses.q18.question: We will use an evidence accumulation model, the liner ballistic accumulation model (LBA) with a focus on DR (drift-rate) and the across-trial SD of drift-rate (SV).
registration_responses.q19.question:
In this study we will use the method of fitting a hierarchical Bayesian evidence-accumulation model. This hierarchical method estimates parameters for each individual separately, but constrain these estimations with the population distribution (see Lin & Strickland, in press, Appendix, for details).

The evidence-accumulation model that we will use is the liner ballistic accumulation model (LBA). In its more standard applications, this model contains of five parameters: drift rate (v), the drift rate standard deviation (SV), non-decision time, starting point (SP) and response threshold (b) (St0- the range of non-decision time, is usually fixed at zero, since adding it to the model substantially increases fitting time, and since usually there is no substantial question that relates to it).

In this study we will use a method of model comparison to test some of our hypothesis. The fundamental idea in this method is to fit several different LBA models, and to decide which model fits the data best. To do so, we will create the null model (M1) with all its parameters set to be equal across different levels of the dependent variable in question. Then, we will create five more models (M2-M6), which in every one of those models a different parameter will set as a function of the dependent variable. The null model will serve as a comparison model to the other models. 

Because hierarchical modeling is a time-consuming process, we will use hierarchical modeling only for our main hypotheses. In addition, in order to interpret the data obtained from the hierarchical analysis, the Gelman-Robin index for each individual and for all subjects together must be less than 1.1. If we won't meet this requirement, or if the hypotheses under examination is not a main hypothesis, we will use simpler methods for estimating the model parameters. The simpler method treats the data as if they came from "one big subject".  This approach is based on maximum likelihood estimation, and issues BIC values for comparative model fit assessment. This method will conduct using 'rtdis' or 'glba' R packages.  Any model that will have a significant smaller DIC or BIC then M1, will account as a model that fit the data the best. This method will be used by us in the analyses of few of our hypothesis.

To test our hypothesis that emotional awareness obeys Weber's law, we first need to show that the LBA model is suitable to find evidence to Weber’s law even for physical stimuli. We thus intend to show that the LBA model can detect Weber's law for the perception of ellipses height and width. We term the related hypothesis “tool-validity hypothesis” (TVH) to mark the fact that it is not a core hypothesis. To do so, we will use the model comparison method, and fit several different LBA models to ellipses height and width responses. Model 1 (TVH-M1) is the null model with all its parameters set to be equal across different levels of the ellipses height and width. In Model 2 (TVH-M2), DR is a function of actual height and width. In model 3 (TVH-M3), SV will set as a function of the ellipse's height and width. We expect that in TVH-M7, SV will increase linearly with stimulus intensity, while DR will increase as the ellipse's height and width will move farther away from a perfect circle. If TVH-M7 is shown to be superior over TVH-M2 and TVH-M3, this will support our prediction. In every one of the four remaining models (TVH-M4- TVH-M6), a different parameter (SP, non-decision, b) will set as a function of the different levels of the ellipse's height and width. We will choose the best model to fit the data, based on the DIC or BIC differences between the models (significantly smallest DIC/BIC).  

In a case that less than 75% of the subjects will fit more to one model compared to the other model (can be deduced by the DIC differences for each subject in both models), we will perform another analysis. For this analysis we will randomly split the data into two separate data sets, so that each subject's trials will be equally distributed between the two sets of data. We than re-run the model with both new data sets, and examined whether the percentage of subjects to fit one model compared to the other model remain almost the same. If the percentage will remain quite like the percentages of the first analysis, we can conclude that the differences between both models are not coincidental. 
If our hypothesis is not supported by the data, we have two options: First, the LBA model is not suitable to express Weber's law. The second option is that something in the experimental procedure went wrong, then we can fix it and try again. Importantly, until (or whether) the tool-validity hypothesis is supported is a pre-requisite for testing the core hypothesis which is described next. 

In order to test our core hypothesis (that emotional awareness obey Weber's law), we will compare between several alternative models which are strictly analogous to the models we have described above, except for being applied to (un) pleasantness reports. 

The ellipses task is used for two purposes: (1) to create a validated reference-point to the emotional and gamble tasks. (2) To function as a disguise (subjects will be led to believe that we are examining whether emotional stimulation/ gamble outcomes affect perception of circles area). In order to create a validated reference-point, we will use the method of model comparison as described above, and apply it on the difference between tasks (ellipses, emotional, monetary gains/ losses). We expect to find that the model that will show to be superior over the other models, is the model that allows the SP parameter to vary between tasks. This hypothesis is in accordance with previous work conducted in our lab (Givon et al., 2019). 

As mentioned above, Experiment 3 contains of two groups. We will use the method of model comparison and apply it on the difference between these two groups (Both groups differ in the gambling task, so that one group is asked about the pleasantness of the gambling results while the other group is asked about the size of the gambling results). We do not know which model will show to be superior over the other models, but we only need to show any difference between the two tasks. But, because this is an exploratory analysis, we will use a more stringent criterion to that comparison (BF greater than 10 will considered as significant, twice our original criterion (BF greater than 5)).

We would also like to check for selective influence as means to validate the model and to replicate prior similar validation by Givon et al. (2019). To do so, we will once again use the method of model comparison, and compare between different levels of some of the depended variables (ellipses height and width, intensity, valance, gamble outcomes). We believe that the model that will have the smallest BIC for each of those variables, will be the model that allows the DR and the SV parameters to vary between different levels of the depended variables. If this prediction will be supported, this will serve as evidence for selective influence. As sanity check, we would also aspect to receive higher drift-rate for negative feeling, then for positive felling (as was found in previous work conducted in our lab).

In the third experiment, we will use gamble trials in order to put the emotional stimuli trials on a ratio scale. This will be done by comparing the DR parameter between gambles and emotional stimuli. For example, let us assume that on average, emotional stimulus whose norm is 6, have DR= 0.6. let's also assume that on average, for a gamble trial in which the participant has won two NIS, its drift rate is also around 0.6. in this case we will say that the pleasantness associated with seeing an emotional stimulus whose norm is 6, is equal to that associated with winning 2 NIS, and since NIS is on a ratio scale, we will be able to anchor DR (and SV) which are also on a ratio scale to another ratio scale. We will repeat the same procedure on all the (grouped by normative rating) emotional stimuli. Note that we are assessing the validity of Weber’s Law on two levels. One level is ordinal: whether SV increases with stimuli intensity. The other level is a ratio-scale level, that requires validation of the ratio-scale properties of DR and its relationship to the NIS scale.

In addition to examining our central hypothesis, we sought to decide on further debate from within the realm of emotion. There are two approaches for measuring affect rating. The first is the bipolar framework which employs a single bipolar scale ranging from positive to negative, and an additional arousal scale ranging from low to high. The second approach is the bivariate framework which employs that positivity and negativity are two different dimensions, and that arousal is not a dimension (that arousal is dependent on the negative and positive dimensions). 

In order to help decide between these hypotheses, we will use the polarity correspondence principle. This principle argues that when a stimulus and a response alternative correspond, the response selection will be faster than when they do not, and this will be primarily driven by the drift-rate (DR).  Another important term is Markedness. According to the Markedness theory, a term is unmarked when it is the dominant part within a dimension. A marked term is the less dominant part in that dimension. Markedness and polarity together can help decide between the bi-polar and unipolar approaches to valence.  

We specifically hypothesize (under the unipolar hypothesis) that DR will be higher for both positive and negative (unmarked, under the unipolar approach) when the response is made with the right hand (unmarked) compared to a left-hand response (marked). However, if the bipolar approach is correct, then the expectation is for faster responses when pleasant-unpleasant are mapped to right-left. In order to verify our hypothesis, we will compare RT between two groups of subjects (one group responds "pleasant" with their right hand, while the other group responds "pleasant" with their left hand). If we will find support for our hypothesis, we will also use the method of model comparison the check our hypothesis at the level of the DR.

We note that there is also the possibility that the response code from the ellipses\ gambling task will affect the responses and will thus make it difficult to test our hypothesis in the present design. Another interference can happen due to the classifying of the stimulus as pleasant or unpleasant (that one word is the negation of the other), or because subjects will never classify the stimulus as neutral. In those cases, we will consider conducting another experiment containing the emotional task only, with a different classifying task.

q1.value: Effect of Early Surgery vs Endoscopy Approach on Outcomes in Patients with Chronic Pancreatitis: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q4.value: To evaluate the differences in outcomes between surgery vs endoscopy approach in patients with chronic pancreatitis

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will include randomized controlled trials comparing endoscopic versus surgical intervention in patients with chronic pancreatitis.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Two review authors will independently screen titles and/or abstracts of studies retrieved using the search strategy and those from additional sources to identify studies that potentially meet the inclusion criteria outlined above. The full text of these potentially eligible studies will be retrieved and independently assessed for eligibility by two review team members. Any disagreement between them over the eligibility of particular studies will be resolved through discussion with a third reviewer.

The data to be extracted will include: authors and published information; study setting; study population and participant characteristics; details of the intervention and control conditions; recruitment and study completion rates; outcomes and times of measurement; indicators of acceptability to users; suggested mechanisms of intervention action; information for assessment of the risk of bias.

The primary outcome is painful relief, which are defined by the included trials, because pain is a subjective outcome and many different scores are used in the included trials. Secondary efficacy outcomes are partial pain relief (defined as a decrease in pain of at least 50% compared to baseline), complete pain relief, quality of life, duration of hospital stay, exocrine insufficiency, and endocrine insufficiency

All meta-analyses will be performed using RevMan (5.3.3; The Cochrane Collaboration). Analyses for all outcomes are done on an intention-to-treat basis. For dichotomous outcomes, we calculate risk ratios (RR) and 95% confidence intervals using the Mantel-Haenszel approach. A P value of < 0.05 is set for statistical significance. If significant heterogeneity is not present (I2<50%), we will use fixed effects models to pool outcomes; we use random effects models when significant heterogeneity is present (I2≥50%). We assesse the overall meta-analysis for small study effects using a visual estimate of the funnel plot and would perform Egger’s test, Begg’s test, and Harbord’s test of heterogeneity.

q4.value: To investigate whether vitamin D supplementation is associated with lower mortality in critically ill patients.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Inclusion criteria: 
(1) Population: adults admitted to ICU
(2) Intervention: administration of vitamin D (regardless of the type, dose, duration, or route of administration)
(3) Comparison: placebo.
(4) Outcome: The primary outcome: all caused mortality; second outcomes: hospital mortality, length of ICU, or length of hospital stay.
(5) Study design: randomised controlled trials.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The following electronic databases will be searched: the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) (The Cochrane Library), Embase (Ovid), and MEDLINE (Ovid). The search strategy will include only terms relating to or describing the intervention.

Keywords will be customized to database-specific indexing terms, e.g. the use of Medical Subject Headings (MeSH terms). As appropriate, the terms and their substitutes will be combined using Boolean connectors (AND/OR/NOT).

The search strategy will follow the PICO format, and similar search strategies will be used on the different databases.

In addition to the electronic searches, a manual search of the bibliographies and references of the identified articles will also be carried out.

Search filters: no language restrictions
Search dates: from database inception to date.

Two review authors will independently screen titles and/or abstracts of studies retrieved using the search strategy and those from additional sources to identify studies that potentially meet the inclusion criteria outlined above. The full text of these potentially eligible studies will be retrieved and independently assessed for eligibility by two review team members. Any disagreement between them over the eligibility of particular studies will be resolved through discussion with a third reviewer.

The data to be extracted will include: authors and published information; study setting; study population and participant characteristics; details of the intervention and control conditions; recruitment and study completion rates; outcomes and times of measurement; indicators of acceptability to users; suggested mechanisms of intervention action; information for assessment of the risk of bias.

The primary outcome: all caused mortality; 
second outcomes: hospital mortality, length of ICU, or length of hospital stay.

We will synthesize the results using the random-effects models for all outcomes. The risk ratio (RR) along with 95% confidence intervals (CI) will be calculated for dichotomous data, and the mean difference (MD) along with 95% CI were used to describe the continuous data. A 2-tailed P value of < 0.05 will be set for statistical significance. Statistical inconsistency will be quantified by use of the I² statistic, with I² values exceeding 50% representing high heterogeneity.
