data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Gender and generic language use in psychology articles

sample.value: We have a corpus of 1,149 articles available to us. Based on the attrition rate from Lerchenmueller et al. (10.7 million articles in full sample, 6.8 million available from the .9 probability threshold), we anticipate that we will have at least 730 articles available for which author gender can be determined.

analyses.value:
Author data collection: Gender of all authors will be collected using Genderize (as was done by Lerchenmueller et al., 2019) using the CSV tool on https://genderize.io/. We will provide descriptives of the breakdown of gender in our sample.

Analysis 1: Linear regression (DV: proportion of generic language in titles, highlights, and abstracts) with the following predictors: 
(a) % of female authors
(b) whether first author is female
(c) whether last author is female
(d) the interaction between b and c

Analysis 1b. If the model fails to converge, we will run as separate analyses (% female, 1st author female, last author female, 1st AND last author female).

Analysis 1c. If we do not find a significant negative association between author gender composition and generic language use, we will perform a closer replication of Lerchenmueller et al. (2019)’s main analysis. Specifically, we will include the % of female authors, the author gender category (first and last authors both female vs. not), and the total number of authors as predictors of the proportion of generics. We are excluding the following predictors included by Lerchenmueller et al. (2019):
 
Year, because we have a more limited year range (2015 and 2016 in our data compared to 2002 to 2017 in their sample)

Impact factor, because again we have a more limited range (all journals had IF < 10 in our data, compared to groups of journals > 10 and < 10 in their sample).

MeSH headings, because there is not a standardized list of keywords in the field of psychology comparable to Medical Subject Headings (MeSH).

Analysis 2. If we do observe the predicted effect, we will perform a follow-up analysis to examine whether the effect holds up when significant predictors from our prior study (SES reporting and language reporting; DeJesus et al., 2019) are added.

To further examine the possible relation between gender and generic language use, we will perform two analyses based on specific types of generics coded in the original study (DeJesus et al., 2019):

Analysis 3a. Are women more likely to use hedges? In the original study, we identified a type of generic statement that included some type of qualifier, such as “these results suggest” (followed by a generic statement) or including words like “perhaps” or “may” in the description of the results. We hypothesize a positive association between female authors and hedged generics. To test this hypothesis, we will repeat Analysis 2 but with the proportion of hedged generics in the title, highlights, and abstract as the dependent variable (rather than overall use of generics).

Analysis 3b: Are men more likely to use bare generics? In the original study, we identified a type of generic statement that was “unqualified and not linked to any particular study, such as ‘infants make inferences about social categories’” (DeJesus et al., 2019, pg. 2) and we hypothesize a negative association between female authors and bare generics. To test this hypothesis, we will repeat Analysis 3a but with the proportion of bare generics in the title, highlights, and abstract as the dependent variable (rather than hedged generics generics).

outliers.value:
Genderize provides a probability that its gender categorization is correct (0-1). Lerchenmueller et al. used a threshold of .9 in their main analysis (and provided other thresholds in their supplemental materials). Genderize also does not return a categorization for names it has not previously encountered and can have issues with names that have accents and other special characters (perhaps due to using the CSV tool).

Given that our sample size is smaller (1,149 articles compared to 10.7 million), we will take the following steps to account for missing data (i.e., on those names for which the probability in Genderize is less than .9 or not generated):

1.	Coders will report whether they think that each name is female, male, or if they cannot tell.
2.	Coders will first each code a set of 20% of the missing names (randomly selected from the entire set of missing names) and reliability will be assessed.
3.	If coders are reliable, then coders will proceed to code the remaining names. Coders will code all the names (rather than splitting the set and performing independent coding) and reliability will be checked again at the end of the coding.
4.	If coders are reliable and agree that a name is either female or male, we will update the author’s gender.
5.	If coders disagree with each other on a name, or if they agree that they cannot tell the name’s gender, that name will still be missing data (rather than attempting to resolve disagreements by discussion or additional coding).

For the proportion of female authors, we will only include authors with gendered names (i.e., that were coded by Genderize or supplemented with the coding just described). For example, if a paper has 7 authors and Genderize/coders concluded that 4 are female, 2 are male, and 1 is unknown, the proportion would be 4/(4+2) = .67. However, the total author count variable will include all authors (regardless of gender categorization).

dependent.value: The dependent variable will be the proportion of generic language used in titles, highlights, and abstracts from 1,149 papers published in 2015-16 in 11 psychology journals (reported in DeJesus et al., 2019).

conditions.value: n/a (this study does not include human participants)

hypothesis.value: Does the use of generic language in published psychology papers vary based on author gender? This study uses an existing dataset of generic language use in psychology papers (DeJesus, Callanan, Solis, & Gelman, 2019) and tests whether author gender is related to generic language used based on the finding that life science articles with a male first or last author were more likely to use positive language, particularly in high impact clinical journals (Lerchenmueller, Sorenson, & Jena, 2019). The authors of the prior work (i.e., Lerchenmueller et al.) described the positive words they selected as relevant for self-promotion (such as “novel”), and we hypothesize that the broad, universal claims implied by generic language could serve a similar function.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: Gender and generic language use in psychology articles
registration_responses.sample: We have a corpus of 1,149 articles available to us. Based on the attrition rate from Lerchenmueller et al. (10.7 million articles in full sample, 6.8 million available from the .9 probability threshold), we anticipate that we will have at least 730 articles available for which author gender can be determined.
registration_responses.analyses:
Author data collection: Gender of all authors will be collected using Genderize (as was done by Lerchenmueller et al., 2019) using the CSV tool on https://genderize.io/. We will provide descriptives of the breakdown of gender in our sample.

Analysis 1: Linear regression (DV: proportion of generic language in titles, highlights, and abstracts) with the following predictors: 
(a) % of female authors
(b) whether first author is female
(c) whether last author is female
(d) the interaction between b and c

Analysis 1b. If the model fails to converge, we will run as separate analyses (% female, 1st author female, last author female, 1st AND last author female).

Analysis 1c. If we do not find a significant negative association between author gender composition and generic language use, we will perform a closer replication of Lerchenmueller et al. (2019)’s main analysis. Specifically, we will include the % of female authors, the author gender category (first and last authors both female vs. not), and the total number of authors as predictors of the proportion of generics. We are excluding the following predictors included by Lerchenmueller et al. (2019):
 
Year, because we have a more limited year range (2015 and 2016 in our data compared to 2002 to 2017 in their sample)

Impact factor, because again we have a more limited range (all journals had IF < 10 in our data, compared to groups of journals > 10 and < 10 in their sample).

MeSH headings, because there is not a standardized list of keywords in the field of psychology comparable to Medical Subject Headings (MeSH).

Analysis 2. If we do observe the predicted effect, we will perform a follow-up analysis to examine whether the effect holds up when significant predictors from our prior study (SES reporting and language reporting; DeJesus et al., 2019) are added.

To further examine the possible relation between gender and generic language use, we will perform two analyses based on specific types of generics coded in the original study (DeJesus et al., 2019):

Analysis 3a. Are women more likely to use hedges? In the original study, we identified a type of generic statement that included some type of qualifier, such as “these results suggest” (followed by a generic statement) or including words like “perhaps” or “may” in the description of the results. We hypothesize a positive association between female authors and hedged generics. To test this hypothesis, we will repeat Analysis 2 but with the proportion of hedged generics in the title, highlights, and abstract as the dependent variable (rather than overall use of generics).

Analysis 3b: Are men more likely to use bare generics? In the original study, we identified a type of generic statement that was “unqualified and not linked to any particular study, such as ‘infants make inferences about social categories’” (DeJesus et al., 2019, pg. 2) and we hypothesize a negative association between female authors and bare generics. To test this hypothesis, we will repeat Analysis 3a but with the proportion of bare generics in the title, highlights, and abstract as the dependent variable (rather than hedged generics generics).

attributes.title: Evaluating Zooming and Overview+Detail Interfaces for Data Visualization in Immersive Environments
attributes.description: A controlled user study compare zooming and overview+detail interfaces in virtual reality (VR).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Evaluating Zooming and Overview+Detail Interfaces for Data Visualization in Immersive Environments

other.value: We will collect 3D positions and rotations of the controllers, headset and visual representations in real-time. But we are still unsure about how we are going to analyze them. We will also collect demographic information from participants, but due to the limited sample size, we may not get useful findings.

analyses.value: Linear mixed modeling will be used if the distribution or transformed distribution of the collected data is a normal distribution. The Friedman test will be used otherwise.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants whose average performance is worse than three sigmas from the mean of all participants.

dependent.value: We will record both the time and answer for each trial. We will also record the number of interactions the participant conducted in each trial. After each task, we will ask the participant to fill in a questionnaire asking about their confidence level, mentally demanding level, physically demanding level with each visual representation as well as ranking them. At the end of the study, we will also ask the participant to rate the overall usability of visual representations.

conditions.value: Four conditions (visual representations): a) zooming, b) zooming with an overview, c) room-sized, and d) room-sized with an overview.

hypothesis.value:
Screen space is one of the most crucial resources for visualizing information. When visualizing big data on a 2D screen, it is not practical to show the detail of every data point. Interactions (e.g., zooming and overview+detail) are essential for users to navigate to areas of interest and then check specific details. This design pattern also follows the famous Shneiderman's mantra --- "Overview first, zoom and filter, then details-on-demand."

Immersive displays, such as virtual and augmented reality headset, can render large size visualization around the user. The key question is: presenting detail in large display sizes, providing interactive techniques or combining both, which is the most beneficial way for the user to access detail information for big data in immersive environments.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Workplace Studies - Mental model of money, calories, sleep and exercise

other.value:
Demographic information is also being collected. 

Secondary analyses:
We don't have any directional hypotheses, so all analyses will be exploratory.

Secondary analyses:
1. For our primary DV (self-reported health score), we will compare the estimated means (and corresponding 95% CIs and error bars) in each condition to each other. We will look at the pattern of results graphically.   

2. Correlation between self-reported health score and skip (skip vs. more). It is not clear, particularly for the nutrition, whether skipping dinner is considered good or bad for nutritional health. 

3. Linear regression of health score on skip (skip vs. more) to check for directional effect. We hypothesize that (skip = skip) questions will be associated with a lower health score for all conditions (taking into account that financial health is reverse coded), while we are not sure about the sign of the (skip = more) questions.

sample.value: We are going to collect as many participants as possible from the Research Bundle Days (February 26/27/28, 2020) at Duke University.

analyses.value:
We will run a mixed-effects model on the self-reported health score, with random effects being participant ID, and a 3x4x2x3 fixed effect interaction of the following form: 
 y ~ time * condition * skip * frequency + (1|id)

We will then run an ANOVA on the mixed-effects model to check for any main effects or interactions between the conditions. To adjust for multiple comparisons, we will set our alpha level to 0.005. We don't have any directional hypotheses.

outliers.value:
Exclusions: 
Only observations of participants who completed the entire study will be included.

dependent.value:
Our main dependent variable is a self-reported financial health / nutritional health / sleep hygiene / physical health score that is being measured on a scale of 0 to 100, with 0 being extremely poor, and 100 being excellent. 

Self-reported financial health will be reverse scored on all skip (skip vs. more) questions. The interpretation is thus "saving" instead of "spending".

conditions.value:
We have a total of 24 scenarios: 4 condition (money, eat, sleep, exercise) x 2 skip (skip vs. more) x 3 frequency (1/2/3 times per week). Participants are first asked about their health score in each of the four domains: money, eat, sleep, exercise. They are then asked to evaluate their financial health / nutritional health / sleep hygiene / physical health for each of the 24 scenario three times, with a different time horizon each time: end of the week / month/ three months. 

This is a within-subject study. All questions within a condition (money, eat, sleep, exercise) are grouped. Randomization occurs on a condition level as well as on a skip-level.

hypothesis.value:
We want to understand people's mental model of money, calories, sleep, and exercise. (How) do people differ in their view of calories, sleep, exercise, and money? Do people have an interest rate for calories, sleep, and exercise?
This is an exploratory study. We do not have any hypotheses.

question2a.value: N/A because this is a correlational design

question2b.value:
1. Category learning performance - mean correctness on category learning trials 

2. Feature Inference performance - mean correctness on feature inference trials

question10b.value:
MATERIALS/STIMULI

The stimuli will consist of two novel categories of cartoon monsters called “Mizulees” and “Nedrils”. The stimuli vary along four binary feature dimensions: type of horns, type of arms, type of marks, and type of eyes. The category structure consists of (a) one diagnostic feature that separates the two categories (the horns); (b) one feature equally distributed across both categories (the eyes); and (c) two features assigned into a pair of correlated features and equally distributed across both categories (the arms and the marks). Correlated feature pairs are feature dimensions that always occur together, regardless of category membership. All possible feature combinations were made, generating a total of 8 unique monsters per category. For the feature inference test, various images (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, tree, etc.) were used to hide the monsters so that only one feature was shown.

PROCEDURE:

Participants will be seated with the experimenter while doing the experiment. Instructions will be read out to all participants. 

The trial orders will be randomized for each participant to avoid any order effects. 

For the first task participants will see a monster appear in the middle of the screen and will have to categorize the monster based on if the participant thinks the monster is a “Mizulee” or a “Nedril”. Participants make responses by pressing either the left or right arrow key corresponding to the monster category. This task will contain 32 trials where after making a response, the participant will be told whether they were correct or incorrect. Each monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and at this time, the participants have to make their response. The monster will remain on the screen for an additional 1 second so that the participants have a chance to look over the features. 

The second task will be feature inference and consist of 14 two alternative forced-choice trials. The monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and will be covered by an object (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, etc.) Only one feature of the monster will be visible to the participant. Two choices of the matching feature will be displayed on the bottom of the screen and participants must choose which feature they think corresponds to the feature seen on the monster. This judgement will be based on what the participant learned about the monster categories in the learning phase. There is a total of 4 correlations trials with correct answers, and 10 control trials with no right or wrong answer. This was done to alleviate any carry-over effects from the previous trial, as well as, allow for more trials in this phase.

The study will end with a thank you slide, and participants will be given credit for participation.

question4b.value: The participants must be between the ages of 4- to 9-years old. They must have normal or corrected vision. They must also not be diagnosed with an attention disorder.

question5b.value: The data will be collected from email recruiting children in the community who are between the ages of 4- to 9- years old. The data will be collected using a computer on which the children will be completing the computer task.

question6b.value:
The planned sample size according to G*Power is 27 participants. To account for 6% attrition, the sample size will be 29 participants.

Based on an effect size determined from previous literature (r = 0.49) in this area, the software G*Power was used to calculate the sample size. The power was set to 0.8 and the alpha was set to .05. This is for a two-tailed test.

question7b.value: We will stop once the planned sample size is achieved.

a) missing and/or erroneous
b) demographic exclusions
c) data-based outlier criteria
d) method-based outlier criteria (e.g. too short or long response times).
e) children who learn the category rule
- an individual will be considered to have learned the category rule if they get more than 60% of trials correct and have peak/plateaued learning in the last 5 trials (to ensure that they still know the rule)

question7c.value: We will omit cases with the missing data and analyze the remaining data. Listwise deletion will be used.

question9c.value: At the moment there are no anticipated data transformations. All data transformation, if ever done, will be reported and justified in the report.

question1a.value:
1. We predict that there is a trade-off when children learn categories:
A) Children who struggle to learn unidimensional category rules during learning will show a greater knowledge of feature correlations.

question2a.value: N/A since this is a correlational design

question3a.value: There will be no variable check in this experiment because there is no manipulation.

question5a.value:
Selective attention allows us to focus on features that are predictive of category membership and ignore "irrelevant " stimuli. However, this serves as a caveat when category members have common features independent of category membership. These features would be considered irrelevant because they hold no information about what category a member belongs to. There is a debate as to whether or not children are able to selectively attend, and if they are unable, do they pick up on the extraneous features because of their divided attention (Deng & Sloutsky, 2015; Rabi, Miles & Minda, 2015)

Deng and Sloutsky (2015) claimed that children pay attention to extraneous features and learn category rules. In their study, they found that children relied more on probabilistic features regardless of the condition. On the other hand, Rabi and Minda (2014) suggest that children are not holistic learners and can selectively attend. Perhaps, there is too much information to learn with extraneous features that selectively attending is an easier learning strategy. 

Children are presumed to perform better in tasks that involve picking up on correlated features because children struggle to selectively attend. For instance, Kemler (1984) was able to demonstrate how using fictitious categories allowed children to learn family resemblance-structured categories more efficiently than categories that had a single defining feature. The children in the Kemler study were unable to extract information about the single defining feature categories due to their lack of selective attention. However, they were able to learn the family resemblance categories due to their ability to retain information about the non-deterministic features.

question6a.value:
Since there is a debate in the literature on how children learn categories, there are competing theories that lead to two different outcomes. 

If children are unable to selectively attend but learn the feature correlations, this would support the theory that children are holistic learners. However, if children are unable to learn the category and unable to pick up on the common correlated extraneous features, then children are not holistic learners.

question1c.value:
1. Category learning performance: will be calculated by the mean correct and incorrect trials in the category learning task. In the dataset, the participant's mean correctness score on category learning will be reported. 

2. Feature Inference performance: will be calculated by the mean number of correct and incorrect trials in the feature inference task.

question2c.value: To determine if performance on the category learning test affects sensitivity to feature correlations we will run a Pearson correlation. (i.e. if learning the category affects learning the feature correlations)

question3c.value:
1. Category Learning Performance - DV
2. Feature Inference Performance - DV
3. Participant age - covariate

question4c.value: Participant age may affect the memory load or capacity to hold any amount of information. Ex. older children may be able to store more info than younger children (somewhat can be attributed to working memory).

Participants make responses by pressing either the left or right arrow key corresponding to the monster category. This task will contain 32 trials where after making a response, the participant will be told whether they were correct or incorrect. Each monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and at this time, the participants have to make their response. The monster will remain on the screen for an additional 1 second so that the participants have a chance to look over the features. 

The second task will be feature inference and consist of 14 two alternative forced-choice trials. The monster will appear on the screen for 30 seconds and will be covered by an object (i.e. a cloud, brick wall, etc.) Only one feature of the monster will be visible to the participant. Two choices of the matching feature will be displayed on the bottom of the screen and participants must choose which feature they think corresponds to the feature seen on the monster. This judgement will be based on what the participant learned about the monster categories in the learning phase. There is a total of 4 correlations trials with correct answers, and 10 control trials with no right or wrong answer. This was done to alleviate any carry-over effects from the previous trial, as well as, allow for more trials in this phase.

The study will end with a thank you slide, and participants will be given credit for participation.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
1. Category learning performance: will be calculated by the mean correct and incorrect trials in the category learning task. In the dataset, the participant's mean correctness score on category learning will be reported. 

2. Feature Inference performance: will be calculated by the mean number of correct and incorrect trials in the feature inference task.

To determine if performance on the category learning test affects sensitivity to feature correlations we will run a Pearson correlation. (i.e. if learning the category affects learning the feature correlations)

1. Category Learning Performance - DV
2. Feature Inference Performance - DV
3. Participant age - covariate

Participant age may affect the memory load or capacity to hold any amount of information. Ex. older children may be able to store more info than younger children (somewhat can be attributed to working memory).
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: The participants must be between the ages of 4- to 9-years old. They must have normal or corrected vision. They must also not be diagnosed with an attention disorder.

The data will be collected from email recruiting children in the community who are between the ages of 4- to 9- years old. The data will be collected using a computer on which the children will be completing the computer task.

The planned sample size according to G*Power is 27 participants. To account for 6% attrition, the sample size will be 29 participants.

Based on an effect size determined from previous literature (r = 0.49) in this area, the software G*Power was used to calculate the sample size. The power was set to 0.8 and the alpha was set to .05. This is for a two-tailed test.
We will stop once the planned sample size is achieved.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a) missing and/or erroneous
b) demographic exclusions
c) data-based outlier criteria
d) method-based outlier criteria (e.g. too short or long response times).
e) children who learn the category rule
- an individual will be considered to have learned the category rule if they get more than 60% of trials correct and have peak/plateaued learning in the last 5 trials (to ensure that they still know the rule)
